brief_description of the content in the: The source page describes a rule that checks if the @lombok.Builder annotation is used in JPA entities. The use of this annotation without a defined no-argument constructor can break the JPA specification.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'lombok-builder-no-arg-constructor' checks all classes in the project. If a class has the @Builder annotation, it asserts that there exists a method in the class which is a constructor (name is '<init>') and has no parameters (parameter type is '()V'). If such a method does not exist, it raises an error message stating that the class uses @Builder but does not have a no-argument constructor.
PRE_model_validation: The rule is syntactically correct and follows the RSL syntax. It uses only the built-in functions and does not introduce any new ones. The rule checks for the existence of a no-argument constructor in classes annotated with @Builder, which aligns with the topic and content provided.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. https://www.baeldung.com/lombok-builder - This page explains the use of @Builder annotation in Lombok and mentions that it does not automatically generate a no-arg constructor.
2. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49802254/jpa-entity-with-lombok-builder-and-noargsconstructor - This StackOverflow thread discusses the issue of using @Builder in JPA entities without a no-arg constructor, which can lead to runtime errors.
